The subsidiary loan would be denominated in Jordanian Dinars and carry a market rate of interest. The interest rate would be variable over the full term of the loan and the timing for resetting the rate would be determined at the option of the SMF at the time of drawdown. At each resetting, the new rate would be equivalent to that obtained by the SMF on bonds of comparable duration within the preceding three months, or, in the absence of such a rate, the rate on a ten-year government security plus a premium reflecting the historical market premiums of SMF bonds over treasury securities. The SMF would repay the subsidiary loan in accordance with an amortization schedule similar to that for the Bank loan. SMF lending terms to PFIs would be market-determined and, in the aggregate, would be made in a manner that minimizes interest rate risk for the SMF. SMF loans to PFIs would, at the option of the SMF, be for 3, 5, 7, or 10 year maturities, or other maturities as may be agreed between the Bank and the SMF. Each SMF loan to a PFI would be collateralized by PFI mortgage loans equivalent to 120% of the principal amount of the loan being extended by the SMF. SMF loans to PFIs would be repaid in full at maturity, without repayment of any principal before maturity. Project Objectives and Description: The proposed project is intended to support the Government's strategy to improve the efficiency of the housing and housing finance sectors, promote private sector development in land and housing production, and reduce the Government's role in both sectors. The primary focus of the project would be on housing finance. Through the establishment of a Secondary Mortgage Facility, the project would aim to improve the efficiency with which medium- to longer- term financial flows for mortgage lending are mobilized, to facilitate and foster
 Housing Finance and Urban Sector Reform Project competition in market-based mortgage lending, and to lengthen the term structure of mortgage lending. Through the implementation of institutional and regulatory reforms in the real sector, the project would aim to improve the enabling environment for responsive private sector participation and competition in land and housing development for lower income households. The proposed Bank loan would finance: (a) a line of credit to the SMF of about US$19.0 million to support the first five year period of its mortgage refinancing program (about US$141.0 million equivalent); (b) the establishment costs of the SMF, comprising about US$200,000 for equipment and about US$400,000 for consulting services, training, and technical assistance; and (c) technical assistance services and training totaling about US$400,000 for HUDC, which would be responsible for implementing the reforms in the real sector. Benefits: Principal project benefits, which may take several years beyond the project implementation period to achieve, include: (a) better housing conditions resulting indirectly from greater availability of medium- to longer-term mortgage financing and from private housing development; (b) the financial deepening of the banking system and bond market; (c) improved resource efficiency in meeting the needs of the low and moderate income housing market; and (d) a reduced claim on the Government's budget by the housing sector. Principal beneficiaries would include: (a) low and moderate income households, who should benefit from the lower costs of home ownership resulting from increased efficiency in the real estate market; (b) most borrowers for housing, who should gain from improved access to mortgage finance and lengthened mortgage maturities; (c) banks and investors, who should be able to utilize the SMF to gain substantial improvements in operational management and efficiency; and (d) the Government, which should be able to reduce budgetary expenditures and transfer much of the risks associated with housing development to the private sector. Risks: The major project risks relate to the SMF, which involves considerable risk overall. First, there is a risk that loan demand from PFIs may not materialize as early as forecast, or in the volume estimated. Second, there is a risk that SMF bond operations to raise funds to meet loan demand may develop more slowly than anticipated, either because it may take longer than anticipated for the SMF to become proficient in bond operations, or because the market may take longer than anticipated to accept bonds that are marketed without a government guarantee. The SMF may not be viable without a guarantee of the initial SMF bonds, subject to a sunset provision. This risk would be mitigated partly by the amount of initial capitalization of the SMF, the ownership participation of the CBJ, and the subordination by the SMF of debt service on the subsidiary loan relative to payments on SMF bonds. Should any of these risks unfold, the disbursement of the proposed Bank loan could be adversely affected. Overall, the risks are considered acceptable when viewed in relation to the expected benefits of the SMF, and in relation to the amount of resources being placed at risk. Under the institutional and regulatory reform component, there is a risk that internal opposition could weaken the Government's resolve to implement the reforms, since they would reduce the public sector's role in land development. Recent actions taken by the Government and HUDC should mitigate this risk.

 THE HASHEMITE KINGDOM OF JORDAN HOUSING FINANCE AND URBAN SECTOR REFORM PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. THE HOUSING FINANCE AND URBAN SECTORS A. Sector Background 1.1 Housing is an important part of the Jordanian economy; it accounted for about one-fourth to one- half of gross fixed capital formation during the period 1985 to 1991. Excluding the refugee camps, the annual demand for new housing units is estimated at about 22,000. The contribution of the construction sector to GDP (in constant prices), of which housing forms an important part, averaged around 8 percent per annum between 1988 and 1992. In the low income housing market, a 1993 Bank poverty assessment found no major housing quantity problems, but occupancy rates of about 3.3 persons per room suggest some overcrowding. In the urban areas where about 70 percent of the total population live, overall access to infrastructure services is high; however, the infrastructure is currently facing increasing demand and many older networks have deteriorated substantially.2 1.2 Like many countries, Jordan for many years has pursued policies and strategies emphasizing public sector responsibility for meeting the basic housing needs of low and moderate income households. In the real sector, government housing agencies were established to develop and service land and housing; their sustainability depended on preferential tax, fee and legal treatments, and priority access to government land, property rights and subsidized financing. The public sector housing agencies were merged in 1992 to form the Housing and Urban Development Corporation (HUDC), whose mandate includes the development, sale and mortgage financing of land and housing targeted to lower income households, and also the formulation of housing policy. In recent years, the Government has been reducing HUDC's direct production role in the sector by largely limiting it to land development activities. HUDC enjoys all of the privileges of government agencies; has access to government land for development purposes; a government guarantee against its debts; and authority to issue debentures. It currently has a staff of about 600, substantially in excess of current needs, as well as a large portfolio of raw land and other real estate assets, and a financial portfolio of subsidized mortgage loans. Its mortgage portfolio has been financed by loans and credits funded by the Government, and is currently valued at about JD65 million. In recent years, however, interest earned on financial assets has been HUDC's principal source of revenues, accounting for about 50 percent of total revenues. Land development has accounted for about 25 percent of revenues. Its land holdings range from a large number of small plots in developed areas with high values per square meter, to large tracts in prime areas ready for development and large tracts in areas not likely to be developed for many years. / Home ownership is high (about 75 percent), even for the poor; vacancy rates are high (11 percent); and the share of permanent housing is also high (about 97 percent). Nevertheless, there are emerging problems that are exacerbated by Jordan's high urban population growth and household formation rates (about 5.7 percent and 4.0 percent per annum, respectively). Average household size is now about 7.0 persons. 2 / Piped water is available to about 97 percent of the urban population but supply is intermittent for a significant proportion of urban dwellers. More than 55 percent of all urban households are connected to the sewer system. Solid waste collection is generally adequate, and about 99 percent of the population has access to electricity. Primary urban road networks are well developed and generally of good quality, and access roads and internal roads in low and middle income settlements are adequate in most areas. Upgrading in many low income areas is nearly completed, with the exception of the refugee camps.
 2 Housing Finance and Urban Sector Reforrn Project 1.3 Similarly, in the financial sector, the Government has been intervening in housing finance thtrough its sponsorship and subsidization of the Housing Bank (HB). HB is privately owned but with management under the control of the Government. HB has been able to offer housing loans at below-market rates (as low as 7 percent) and for longer termns (up to 15 years) than other banks because of a variety of special privileges. In recent years, however, HB has increasingly acted along the lines of a regular commercial bank, with direct loans to home buyers accounting for less than 15 percent of its portfolio. In 1996, the Government is planning to introduce amendments to the Housing Bank Law to reduce most of HB's special privileges. As discussed below, removing these and all remaining privileges is essential to the further development of housing finance, but could also reduce the affordability of housing for low and moderate income households. 1.4 In addition to supporting HB, the Government has provided below-market funding to HUDC for its clients and also large amounts of low-rate or zero-rate financing for military personnel. The other banks, particularly the Jordan Islamic Bank, make a modest amount of market rate loans, generally for fixed rates for only 5-7 years, targeted primarily to upper-income households. Cash savings, particularly in the form of remittances, provides the bulk of funding for housing. Overall, total housing lending is less than 10 percent of GDP. 1.5 The subsidized housing finance provided by the Government has imposed a budgetary burden; in 1993, the present value of mortgage rate subsidy obligations held by the Government totaled about $67 million equivalent. The subsidies frequently did not reach the lowest income groups. The access of the housing agencies to government land and subsidized government finance, combined with the absence of strict market discipline, has occasionally led to major inefficiencies in the use of scarce government resources. One large public housing scheme, for example, significantly misjudged the market, and required a large government financial bailout of the agencies involved. Today, the Government wants to withdraw from the subsidization of housing finance and also reduce its role in the real sector. The proposed project would support these goals. B. Policy and Institutional Constraints 1.6 An Incomplete Market in Housing Finance. Many of the conditions for an effective housing finance system in Jordan are in place (Annex 1). The financial system includes the Housing Bank, 17 commercial banks and one savings bank, as well as the Amman Financial Market (AFM) which is becoming a vibrant equities market. In addition, the macroeconomic environment and legal framework are conducive to an effective housing finance system; inflation is less than 5 percent per annum, interest rates are liberalized, and the legal system for foreclosure in the event of default is reasonably satisfactory. Nevertheless, market-based mortgage financing has been relatively limited and confined generally to lower risk mortgages for higher income housing. In recent years, only HB and the government housing agencies have made mortgage financing available for the low income market, using various government subsidies. The banking sector relies on deposits (mainly short-term) for funding because the primary and secondary markets in bonds and other term securities, while emerging, are still underdeveloped.3 The shallow securities market limits both the opportunities for the banking sector to raise term finance to fund 3/ Although the AFM has established systems for bond trading, the corporate bond market remains underdeveloped primarily because of: (a) the market's traditional preference for equity; (b) stringent conditions in the Companies Law for issuance of corporate debt; (c) a lack of credit rating mechanisms; and (iv) a customary expectation for govemment guarantees on bond issues. Moreover, the practice of the Central Bank of Jordan has been to repurchase govemment debt at face value. As a result, even private investment and commercial banks have not been able to use bond markets to fund their term lending operations. However, in the Letter of Development Policy for the Economic Reform and Development Loan (ERDL) (Ln. 3947-JO), approved on October 24, 1995, the Govemment has committed to the implementation of financial market and legal reforms in 1996 that should support growth in the bond market.

The current market situation therefore constrains prudent mortgage lending by the banking sector and thus the sector's willingness to engage in a greater volume of longer-terrn mortgage lending.4 1.7 Role of the Private Sector. Although the formnal private sector dominates and operates effectively in the market for middle and high income housing, the emergence of formal private sector solutions to lower income housing problems has been hindered particularly by the private sector's lack of access to the special privileges that have been enjoyed by government housing agencies, including access to land zoned for small plot sizes, and special, lower cost building standards. Only small owner-builders and other informal developers have also operated in the lower income housing market, many operating in accordance with legal building requirements but some operating haphazardly outside the legal framework. Zoning practices have distorted the land market available to the private sector, by setting aside most land in prime urban housing areas for large plot sizes which are unaffordable to low and moderate income households, and which are also inefficient in the use of available infrastructure. C. Government Strategy 1.8 The Government's past reliance on government housing agencies to develop land and housing for the lower income market has exposed the Government to significant commercial risks, allowed inefficiencies to drain resources from the Government's overall development efforts, and undermined the potential role of the private sector. Consistent with Jordan's emphasis in recent years on developing sustainable, private sector solutions to economic problems, the Government intends to shift responsibility to the private sector for developing land and housing for lower income households, and to implement measures to mobilize increased longer-term, market-based financing for mortgage lending. Over time, public sector activities would be increasingly reduced to policy, planning and research and basic upgrading works. The proposed project would support the implementation of this strategy. The Government has recorded its commitment to this strategy and to related policy reforms in a Letter of Sector Policy (LSP) (Annex 2). D. Lessons of Previous Bank Experience 1.9 Since 1979, the Bank has provided support for three sites and services and upgrading projects. The operations were successful in developing new housing, but required subsidies that tended to distort the market, frequently did not reach lower income households, and hindered replication. The Bank has also supported two municipal projects whose sustainability has been jeopardized by structural weaknesses (size, revenue bases) in the targeted secondary cities. The lessons learned are that more fundamental, market- promoting changes are necessary to ensure replicability and economic efficiency, and that these must have the full commitment and support of the Government. The lessons are consistent with Bank-wide experience that has confirmed the importance of several principles relevant to Jordanian circumstances, including the need to separate subsidies from finance and to apply affordability criteria to the design of land use and construction standards. The lessons have been incorporated in the design of the proposed project. 2. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives and Description 2.1 The proposed project is intended to support the Government's strategy to improve the efficiency of the housing and housing finance sectors, promote private sector development in land and housing 4/ Lending maturities are prudently short because of the liquidity and interest rate risks inherent in the potential mismatch of the maturity structures of borrowing and lending. Through the establishment of a Secondary Mortgage Facility (SMF), the project would aim to improve the efficiency with which medium- and longer-term financial flows for mortgage lending are mobilized, to facilitate and foster competition in market-based mortgage lending, and to lengthen the term structure of mortgage lending. The SMF is expected to make mortgage lending more attractive to lenders, by permitting them to reduce the liquidity risks of medium- and longer-term mortgage lending, and also possibly to access funds for housing at a lower effective cost. However, there would be no direct linkages between SMF operations and lending for low-cost housing. 2.2 Through the implementation of institutional and regulatory reforms in the real sector, the project would also aim to improve the enabling environment for responsive private sector participation and competition in land and housing development for lower income households. 2.3 The project would: (a) Establish a Secondary Mortgage Facility, to: (i) indirectly promote medium- to longer- term, market-based financial flows into the mortgage market by providing financial institutions with a source of liquidity for their longer-term lending for mortgages; (ii) raise aggregate financial flows by offering investors medium- to longer-tern bonds of transparently low risk; and (iii) increase liquidity in the bond market by expanding the supply of tradable longer-term securities; and (b) Implement Institutional and Regulatory Reforms, to: (i) reduce the regulatory barriers that constrain the private sector from entering and competing in the lower income housing and land development markets, and from responding efficiently and effectively to market signals and needs; and (ii) reorient the role and mandate of the HUDC to be a facilitator and promoter of private sector development of land and housing for lower income households. 2.4 Bank financing for the proposed project, including contingencies, would comprise: (a) a line of credit to the SMF (about US$19.0 million equivalent); (b) funds to finance the initial establishment costs of the SMF (about US$600,000); and funds to finance consulting services for HUDC's reorientation (about US$400,000). 2.5 Features of the Secondary Mortgage Facility (Annexes I and 3).5 The SMF's draft charter was reviewed during negotiations, and assurances were obtained that the charter would not be amended without the prior agreement of the Bank. Following negotiations of the proposed Bank loan, the SMF was legally established under the Companies Law on June 5, 1996 as the Jordan Mortgage Refinance Company (JMRC). A Board of Directors comprising nine members including the Chairman has been elected. The SMF has ownership participation by all key participants in the financial system (e.g., CBJ, HUDC, Social Security Corporation and banks), and majority ownership is held by twelve private banks. The Government has taken on a minority shareholding to ensure that the SMF is responsive to the needs of both bond investors and mortgage lenders. The Chairman of the Board of the SMF would be the Governor of CBJ, the Deputy Governor of CBJ, or another Board member whom the Governor has approved. The SMF's charter prohibits any single bank (other than CBJ), or private sector participant, from acquiring more than 10 percent ownership of the SMF. The capital of the SMF totals about US$7 million equivalent. The SMF would be the main beneficiary of the proposed Bank loan which would be on-lent from the Government under a Subsidiary Loan Agreement (viz., subsidiary loan). 5/ The conceptual design of the SMF has been formulated in consultation with representatives of the Government, the banking sector, the housing sector, contractual savings institutions, and the private sector, and with advice from the Malaysian SMF, Cagamas Berhad.
 Housing Finance and Urban Sector Reform Project 5 2.6 In accordance with its charter, the SMF would have two main activities and a very narrow mandate to shield it from substantial risk. The first activity would be to refinance mortgage loans originated by commercial banks and other eligible financial institutions regulated by the Central Bank of Jordan (CBJ) (hereinafter referred to as participating financial institutions (PFIs)) on the strength of pledged collateral consisting solely of mortgages on owner-occupied and rental residential housing, which generally comprises the safest part of a bank's loan portfolio. The PFIs would be required to pledge as collateral an amount in mortgages greater than the amount of the SMF refinancing loan (para. 3.5). The SMF would not accept any risks associated with the original mortgage loans (e.g., credit risk, interest rate risk, pre-payment risk); the ownership of the mortgages and all risks would remain with the originating PFI. Eligible PFIs would be financially strong, privately owned institutions that satisfy the CBJ's capital adequacy requirements and all other applicable banking regulations, and that have the institutional capacity to undertake mortgage lending activities. The eligibility criteria for PFIs is summarized in Annex 3. 2.7 The second activity of the SMF would be to raise funds for lending to the PFIs by offering bonds to long-term investors who, at the outset, are expected to comprise mainly the Social Security Corporation (SSC) and possibly insurance companies. The bonds are expected to be offered and appraised in the market without the advantage of a government guarantee. The SSC holds most of the long-term financial savings generated in the economy through pension and retirement funds. Its assets currently total about $1 billion equivalent and are invested mainly in short-term bank deposits, certificates of deposit, bonds and loans. The insurance sector accounts for about 4 percent of the assets of the financial system. The maturities and terms of SMF bonds would be matched to those of SMF loans to the PFIs, except for a spread to cover the expenses of the SMF and a return on its capital. SMF loans to PFIs would be "bullet" loans, which would not be prepayable before maturity unless the bonds issued by the SMF are also prepayable. SMF bonds are expected to be nearly risk-free because they would be backed by mortgage collateral held by the SMF (para. 3.5). In addition, during negotiations, assurances were obtained that debt service on the subsidiary loan would be subordinated by the SMF to payments on its outstanding bonds as a means of providing a measure of confidence and security to potential purchasers of SMF bonds in the absence of explicit government guarantees. In addition, the amortization schedule of the subsidiary loan would be similar to that for the Bank loan to endow it with a maturity structure that would better qualify it as semi-pernanent capital. Potential bond purchasers might also derive a measure of confidence from the CBJ's ownership participation in the SMF. 2.8 During negotiations, assurances were obtained that the SMF would be exempted from limits imposed by the Companies Law upon the issuance of corporate debt. In this regard, the Government is currently working on proposed changes to the Companies Law that would help to facilitate the further development of the bond market. Pending their enactment into law, the Government has obtained the approval of the Issuing Committee, as specified under the provisions of the existing Companies Law, to exempt the SMF from the Law's current limitations on the issuance of bonds. In addition, by December 31, 1996, the Government would formulate and implement appropriate mechanisms to facilitate and streamline the registration and transfer of liens by the SMF. Secondary trading in SMF bonds is expected to emerge gradually among banks and institutional investors as their portfolio requirements change, either through direct placements or through trading on the AFM, which would also facilitate bond purchases by small individual investors. 2.9 During negotiations, assurances were obtained regarding the treatment of SMF bonds with respect to both taxation and the liquidity reserve holdings of banks. Interest derived from SMF bonds would be exempted from taxation in accordance with current tax laws. The cumulative demand for SMF loans by PFIs during the period of the project is estimated to total around JDIOO million (US$141.0 million equivalent), or about JD20-30 million annually. This estimate is conservative when viewed in comparison with the current stock of mortgages held by the banking sector that could possibly qualify for refinancing, estimated at about JDIOO million (about US$140 million equivalent), and in comparison with the annual flow in mortgage financing of about JD35 million (about US$50 million equivalent). Actual levels of activity, however, would depend on conditions prevailing in the financial market and the extent of subsidized housing finance being provided through other market participants. 2.11 Financial Analysis of the SMF (Annex 4). The financial success of the SMF would depend primarily on whether lenders perceive the cost of and features of SMF funding to be attractive relative to funds raised by deposit-taking. The net cost of SMF funds is projected to be somewhat lower than the all-in cost of large deposits. This projection nets out the cost of meeting reserve requirements for deposits (at least 200 basis points) from the spread needed by the SMF to cover its costs of operations (about 135 basis points). However, investors in SMF bonds would require a higher return than on deposits to compensate for differences in tenor, term of rate (if fixed rate bonds), and perceptions of credit risk. If this premium is less than 70 basis points, the refinance rate of the SMF should be no more than the all-in cost of deposits and the other advantages of SMF funding should be costless to the PFIs. 2.12 The second major consideration is the volume of refinancing. The operating and capital costs of the SMF would be relatively fixed, and thus the required spread would depend on volume. The pro-forrna financial projections assume a steady growth towards about JDIOO million in outstanding refinance after four years from the start of operations, a volume sufficient to meet a profitability goal of a 15 percent after- tax return on capital in the fourth or fifth year. This volume reflects a target of refinancing 40 percent of the projected pool of eligible lending after four years from the start of operations. 2.13 Features of the Institutional and Regulatory Reform Measures.7 The proposed reforn measures would support the emergence of an efficient private sector real estate industry responsive to the needs of low and moderate income households. BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Project Benefits 5.1 Principal project benefits, which may take several years beyond the project implementation period to achieve, include: (a) better housing conditions, resulting indirectly from greater availability of medium- and longer-term mortgage financing and from private housing development; (b) the financial deepening of the banking system and bond market; (c) improved resource efficiency in meeting the needs of the low and moderate income housing market; and (d) a reduced claim on the government budget by the housing sector. Principal beneficiaries would include: (a) low and moderate income households, who should benefit from the lower costs of home ownership resulting from increased efficiency in the real estate market; (b) most borrowers for housing, who should gain from improved access to mortgage finance and lengthened mortgage maturities; (c) banks and investors, who should be able to utilize the SMF to improve their portfolio management; and (d) the Government, which should be able to reduce budgetary expenditures and transfer much of the risks associated with housing development to the private sector. B. Economic Analysis 5.2 Economic benefits have only been quantified for the SMF component for which an estimation is given in Annex 8. The commercial viability of the SMF, as indicated in the financial analysis (para. 2.1 1), does not by itself assure that the SMF would generate net economic and social benefits. However, an indicative assessment of such benefits can be derived by estimating the value to banks and households of having access to this form of financial intermediation, which should be reflected over time in the terms and conditions under which banks would be willing to offer housing loans. 5.3 At a minimum, economic benefits are expected to accrue from: (a) for lenders, a reduction in the liquidity risk associated with longer-term housing loans, thereby enabling a reduction in the price and non- price barriers to longer-term borrowing; (b) for mortgagors (households), a combination of lower costs of funds and a longer term on the mortgages being offered, as well as greater interest among banks in pursuing more lending for housing; and (c) improved financial information in the capital market on term structures and risks that should reduce the cost of issuing medium- and long-term corporate debt in Jordan. After taking into account the estimated costs of SMF operations and of the capital committed to the SMF, the economic rate of return (ERR) is expected to fall within the range of 15 to 20 percent. However, the ERR is sensitive to both the size and timing of costs and benefits and, at one lower bound estimation of costs and benefits, the ERR could fall to about 10 percent, while at a higher bound estimation it could exceed 20 percent. 5.4 Other benefits of the SMF, which have not been quantified, are also likely to accrue. The SMF could induce greater public awareness of the importance of analyzing credit risks in the absence of government guarantees, and also possibly help the Government reduce the housing finance subsidies to low and moderate income households which it has been channeling through a special window at the Housing Bank. 5.5 Implicit in this analysis is the counterfactual assumption that the housing finance market in Jordan would remain unchanged in the absence of the SMF. To the extent that other adjustments could take place without the SMF, its benefits are overstated. However, it is difficult to discern signs that the basic nature of the mortgage and bond markets would change anytime soon in the absence of this project. Banks have reiterated their concern about the illiquidity of mortgage lending, the real level of government domestic debt outstanding is shrinking, and bank syndications have almost completely replaced corporate bond issuances.

C. Project Risks 5.6 The most significant project risks relate to the SMF, which is an entirely new venture in Jordan involving considerable risk overall. First, there is a risk that loan demand from PFIs may not materialize as early as forecast, or in the volume estimated. Market behavior is difficult to predict in Jordan; the demand for SMF funds would depend on many factors, such as the willingness of consumers to pay market rates for term finance, the willingness of banks to pay a premium over the cost of deposits to defray risks of illiquidity from mismatching maturities, the linkages between credit demand and private sector development of land and housing, and operating costs of the SMF. Second, there is a risk that SMF bond operations to raise funds to meet loan demand may develop more slowly than anticipated, either because it may take longer than anticipated for the SMF to become proficient in bond operations, or because the financial market may take longer than anticipated to accept bonds that are marketed without a government guarantee. The SMF may not be viable without a guarantee of the initial SMF bonds, subject to a sunset provision. This risk would be mitigated partly by the amount of initial capitalization of the SMF, by the ownership participation of the CBJ, and by the subordination by the SMF of debt service on the subsidiary loan relative to payments on SMF bonds. Third, there is a risk that adverse changes in the macroeconomic framework could hinder SMF operations and the achievement of its objectives. The Government, however, remains committed to and on track with its macroeconomic adjustment program. Should any of these risks unfold, the disbursement of the proposed Bank loan could be adversely affected. Nevertheless, proceeding with the SMF remains justified because the risks are considered acceptable when viewed in relation to the expected benefits and the probability that the SMF would ultimately lead to greater financial market efficiency, and in relation to the amount of resources being placed at risk. 5.7 Under the institutional and regulatory reform component, there is a risk that internal opposition could weaken the Government's resolve to implement the reforms, since they would reduce the public sector's role and privileges in land development. Recent actions taken by the Government and HUDC should mitigate this risk (paras. 2.15 and 2.16). 5.8 After taking into account the nature of the above-mentioned risks and the actions that would be taken to mitigate them, there remains a risk that unanticipated future events could adversely affect the pace of project implementation and the achievement of the project's development objectives. When viewed in the context of the project's expected benefits, this risk is considered acceptable. 6. Most of the Jordanian population is relatively well-housed. The housing sector has not depended heavily on forrnal-sector housing finance to accomplish this achievement. It appears that such financing amounts to less than 10 percent of GDP, in contrast to a figure of 90 percent in the United States and 25 percent in Malaysia, a developing country with higher incomes and a more advanced financial sector. In the aggregate, there is a clear reliance on financing through cash and intra-family financing, especially from remittances. However, the opportunities for expatriate remittances has declined, signalling what will probably be a shift towards greater reliance on formal credit for housing. 2. Most lending for housing and other real estate is currently intermediated through the commercial banking system.' There do not appear to be any accurate public data on the stock or the flow of loans for housing, but it is possible to estimate formal sector lending for housing. At the end of 1994, the Housing Bank (HB) held about JD90 million in loans lent out of its own funds to households for the purchase or improvement of an owner-occupied home. This lending constituted only 17 percent of the HB's loan portfolio. The Jordan Islamic Bank apparently has another JD60 million outstanding. Other banks have not released figures on their long-term mortgage lending, but indicative estimates suggest that, in the aggregate, the total would not exceed JD200 million for all of the banks (about 6 percent of bank credit), plus up to JD200 million in directed credits made at concessional terms funded through other channels.2 This implies a maximum of about JD400 million in housing loans, or almost 10 percent of GDP. 3. Such small exposure to long-term housing lending presumably is due either to conscious risk management on the part of the banks or a lack of interest on the part of households in using bank credit for housing. Most banks express the view that both factors are at play, particularly since the net cost to a mortgage borrower is currently about 13.5 percent for a loan for 7 years, in an economy with inflation under 5 percent since 1991. Moreover, the spread between the borrowing rate and the deposit rate is usually 5 percent or more, suggesting that greater equity investment in housing is preferable to accumulating wealth in financial instruments.3 / The great majority of bank lending for housing is done by the Housing Bank and the Jordan Islamic Bank. A significant additional amount comes directly from government entities, in particular the military, which probably has the largest portfolio of long-term housing loans outstanding. However, there are few public data on the military housing scheme. Beyond the banks and the military, some lending appears to be undertaken directly by private pension plans at a low rate for the benefit of plan participants and by the Social Security Corporation (SSC) for the benefit of certain groups, such as university professors. / This includes about JD65 million held by the Housing and Urban Development Corporation (HUDC), perhaps another JDI00 million outstanding in loans to military personnel, and JD25 million lent by the SSC. 3/ A minor caveat to this view is the fact that earnings on deposits are tax exempt to individuals, while the payment of interest for housing is tax deductible. At the top income tax rate of 30 percent, the after-tax cost of borrowing is only 9.45 percent, but the deduction is limited to JD2,000 per year.

The Risks of Housing Finance. The credit risk associated with residential lending appears to be reasonably low. The maximum loan is for 75 percent of the appraised value of the land and structure. The appraisal is not based on the general prices in the market, but rather on an estimate of what the distress-sale price might be. The legal basis for foreclosure on defaulted loans is relatively strong. Apparently because of concern for appearances, foreclosure has been rarely begun (only after 18 months of delinquency) nor pursued to its conclusion and most defaulted loans are rescheduled or otherwise compromised. Liquidity risk is much more significant. Among banks other than the HB, there appears to be concern that external political, economic, and demographic shocks could affect Jordan. Thus, many observers consider term mis- matching as the most significant risk for lending for housing, thereby creating price and non-price restrictions on access to housing credit. In contrast, due to its special treatment, the HB need not have the same level of concern as other banks about risks to its survival and profitability. In this way, the Government has solved some of the liquidity concerns about mortgage lending. However, it has given these capabilities to a single bank, thereby precluding market-expanding fair competition. 7. Interest rate risk is also associated with housing loans in Jordan. All loans have rates that are legally subject to change if a bank's cost of funds goes up, but this flexibility has never been tested and could be limited by both legal and political considerations. As it is, lender currently absorb small swings in the cost of funds to avoid provoking controversy by changing rates. The net effect, however, is to create more justification for banks to limit their exposure to housing loans. 8. Leveling the Playing Field. The Potential Benefits from Secondary Mortgage Funding I. Creation of a mechanism for facilitating intermediation between truly longer-term financial investors and housing borrowers would permit the banks to reduce or eliminate the liquidity risks of housing lending and also the interest rate risk by generating a source of fixed-rate funding. Moreover, if this intermediation takes the form of homogeneous, nearly riskless securities issued on a large scale, the securities can serve as the basis of expanding the range and capacities of the money market. Such mechanisms are generally known as secondary mortgage funding sources. The term "secondary" is intended to contrast with the "primary" market for mortgages, which consists of financial institutions which make the loans initially. Under this broader understanding of secondary mortgage funding, there is a wide range of altemative approaches being practiced around the world. The appropriateness of any system depends on the circumstances prevailing in the housing and financial markets of the individual country. 12. An institution that makes loans to primary lenders, using mortgages as collateral and funds raised from its own bond issuances, is referred to as a secondary mortgage facility (SMF). The bonds of an SMF can be safer and more liquid than those issued by a single lender because an SMF can independently control / Refer to main text of Staff Appraisal Report.

Several countries have created such special institutions, usually with sponsorship by the Government. One way of viewing an SMF is as a separate institution that pools together as collateral the very best mortgages from several banks or other lending institutions and uses that collateral to offer bonds that are nearly risk-free to long-term investors. The ownership of the mortgages stays with each lender, and the lender and the investors conclude their long-term funding arrangement under the auspices and supervision of the SMF. 13. The presence of a secondary market source of funding for mortgages can, in principle, reduce the costs and liquidity risks that Jordanian banks face in funding housing loans. It could even permit the operation of non-bank financial institutions specializing in housing finance (e.g., mortgage companies). There will be an increase in the access of households to housing if the rates on mortgages are lower, the terms are longer, or simply the banks market and originate housing credit more aggressively because they feel more comfortable with their liquidity situation. The SMF Proposed for Jordan 14. It appears likely that a simple SMF, under which bonds are collateralized by loans to banks and the loans are collateralized by mortgages, would be most suitable for Jordan. Figure 1.1 illustrates how the SMF would operate within the current structure of the Jordanian financial system. Rather than have all of the funds from the SSC, insurance companies and other long-term investors flow to the banks in the form of deposits, some of the funds would flow to the SMF in return for bonds issued by the SMF. The SMF would then make long-term loans to the banks in return for pledges of residential mortgages as collateral. The full credit risks of the mortgage lending would stay with the banks, but the bank could now finance a part or all of those loans with longer-term funds. This is a relatively simple arrangement. The basic legal requirements already exist in Jordan, including legal and institutional infrastructure for the issuance and trading of long-term bonds and the pledging of mortgages as collateral. It is possible to establish the SMF under existing laws for financial companies. 15. The Jordanian SMF would be a financial institution, more like a specialized bank than an entity such as the Amman Financial Market (AFM) or an ordinary operating company. It would make long-term loans to banks; the funds in practice can be used by the bank for any purpose. However, the bank would have to have originated enough qualifying loans for owner-occupied housing to serve as collateral for the loans from the SMF. In practice, most banks would probably follow the approach of refinancing all or part of their mortgage lending with the SMF, depending on their overall need for funds, the cost of alternative sources of funds, and their desire to lengthen the overall term of their liabilities. / There are, however, a variety of provisions in the Companies Law that could hinder the proper functioning of the SMF, and these have been addressed under the proposed project.

There has not been a successful issuance of long-term bonds in Jordan that was not explicitly guaranteed by the Government. However, many secondary funding mechanisms operate without explicit government guarantees, with investors recognizing that the collateral backing their loans is the best available in the economy, short of the power of money creation that resides only with the government. This is the case of all but one of the four SMFs in the United States and for the Malaysian and French SMFs. Thus, there are grounds for confidence that the SMF would be able to operate without a government guarantee. 22. There would be two major benefits of avoiding such a guarantee. The design of the SMF's institutional and operational modalities has been tailored to the particular circumstances in Jordan and would likely need further development as experience is gained from operations. But this would not assure its success. Success would depend primarily on whether lenders perceive the cost and features of funds obtained through the SMF to be attractive relative to funds raised by deposit-taking. Expectations of Bond Investors 2. For investors, the expected benefits from investing in SMF bonds would comprise low credit risk, a reliable return over the medium term, and potentially a reasonable degree of liquidity. These features can be contrasted with the alternatives of bank deposits and government-guaranteed bonds. As of October 1995, banks were taking large deposits for periods of 6 months to a year at rates between 8.5 percent to 9.0 percent, tax-free. These deposits were not immediately liquid, included some degree of credit risk, and the rates were subject to change at maturity. Government 1 0-year bonds were sold at 9.25 percent and were not expected to be traded. (There was some basis for expecting the implicit yield curve to be fairly flat, because deposit rates in the medium tern could decline if inflation stayed low and U.S. rates declined). However, government bonds have the advantage of eligibility for the required liquidity reserve of banks. Since this provision would also be extended to SMF bonds, banks should be interested in holding and possibly trading them at rates only a little above the rates on government bonds (if fixed) or on CBJ Certificates of Deposit (CDs) (if floating). If the SMF bonds did not offer this feature, the banks would not be interested in holding them at rates much less than the all-in cost of funding, around 11 percent. 3. The above analysis suggests that the banks and long-term investors such as the Social Security Corporation (SSC), insurance companies, and some individuals should be willing to hold the SMF bonds at rates as low as 25-50 basis points over the rate on government bonds. However, the rate would have to be higher if the bonds were not eligible for the liquidity reserve. If the banks are not holders, liquidity would also be diminished, further increasing the required rate. If the market in SMF bonds develops a reasonable degree of liquidity and low transactions costs, the rate could be lower. Expectations of Participating Financial Institutions (PFIs) 4. For PFIs, SMF funding should reduce the interest rate risk of mortgage lending, assuming the bonds and the funds are offered with a matching degree of variability in interest rate that appeals to investors, banks, and borrowers and, since SMF funds are for a longer term, also reduce the liquidity risk of mortgage lending. PFI's should therefore be willing to pay more for SMF funds than the highest stated rate on incremental deposits including the cost of raising and holding the incremental deposits, since SMF funds would substitute for deposits. This premium could be 50 basis points or more. The breakeven lending rate for an additional JD of deposit raised at 9.0 percent is at least 11.0 percent cu..ently (with 14 percent set aside in cash and another 16 percent in CBJ CDs at 8.5 percent). These considerations imply that if the highest stated rate on one-year deposits is 9.0 percent (and is expected to remain so for the next 5 years),

Three distinct benefits are expected from the SMF: (a) a decrease in the liquidity risk of the mortgage portion of bank portfolios, due to an increase in its liquidity; (b) an increase in the ability to borrow for housing, due to a lengthening of the term to maturity in the market-rate loans being offered by lenders; and (c) a decrease in the cost of intermediation for corporate bonds, due to an increase in the liquidity of all corporate bonds. Of these benefits, only the second, the increase in borrowing ability, is
 Annex 5 Page 2 of 12 directly measurable. However, all of the benefits have correlates that are measurable and can be tracked as indicators of the success of the SMF. The SMF project component impacts can be measured most carefully by regularly surveying lenders as to the their cost of funds, their rates and other terms for mortgage lending, the amounts of such lending and perhaps also their narrative perspectives on such lending. Such a survey would be designed under the auspices of the project and conducted by the SMF. 6. Decrease in Liquidity Risk, As discussed in Annexes 4 and 8 on the financial and economic analyses of the SMF, respectively, the banks currently seem to be seeking in their mortgage lending a gross spread of about 250 basis points over their all-in marginal cost of deposits. A portion of this should be related to the illiquidity being introduced into their portfolio by lending long-term for housing. That portion should be reducible to near zero, if the SMF offers lenders a viable option for refinancing their loan portfolio. Such a reduction in the liquidity risk associated with housing loans should be noticeable in two respects. The gross operating spread of lenders in a competitive market should decline over time. A reduction of up to 50 basis points may be achieved within about five years. Also, lenders should be willing to lend for longer terms than the 7 years currently observed (see below). Thus, both of these parameters of market behavior would be used as indicators of development impact. 7. Observing changes in market spread would not be straightforward. Efforts would need to be made to systematically track the average effective rate on mortgage lending, accounting for the offering of discounts to some borrowers and the imposition of various fees that raise the effective rate. Some work would also need to be done on how banks view their all-in marginal cost of funds, as a function of their rate for large deposits and the costs of reserve requirements. 8. Indirect measures of development impact in this regard would also be monitored, including the volume of SMF refinancing activity, the share of outstanding mortgage loans which it refinances, and its achievement of commercial sustainability. The financial projections given in Table 4.2, Annex 4, suggest that the SMF's outstanding portfolio of mortgage refinancings could possibly grow to about JDl00 million after about five years, or an estimated 40 percent of the projected total volume of mortgage loans in Jordan. Other indirect measures of development impact include the self reports of lenders and the appearance of lengthening in the term to maturity for housing loans. The term extension is particularly important because it is the major channel whereby the impacts on the intermediation process create benefits for individual households. But direct measurement of a narrowing of the intermediation spread would be needed to assess whether the SMF has reduced liquidity risks on the outstanding portfolio of housing loans, as it is expected to. 9. Longer Lending Terms. The impact on term to maturity should be relatively easy to measure at lenders other than the Housing Bank. It is commonly noted in Jordan that lenders do not commit funds for longer than 7-8 years, both because of liquidity concerns and because of the perceived limitations of the Ottoman Law on cumulative interest. The average term of new housing loans could possibly increase to about 10 years after about five years. The effect on the overall market may not be so evident because the Housing Bank already offers longer terms on its smaller loans as part of its special role within the banking sector. If and when all of the privileges and subsidies of the HB are removed or extended to other banks, the terms set by the HB relative to the other banks would be of interest. Despite the fact that the HB currently offers loans with longer terms to maturity, there are reasons to expect that increased competition among banks, made possible by the operation of the SMF, will increase the total volume of lending. This is because the HB currently has incentives to limit its lending through non-price rationing, since housing loans are made at below-market interest rates. Competition may force a reduction in any such non-price rationing. All of these dimensions of lender behavior would be tracked through regular surveys by the SMF.

 Annex 8 Page 1 of6 THE HASHEMITE KINGDOM OF JORDAN HOUSING FINANCE AND URBAN SECTOR REFORM PROJECT Economic Analysis of the Secondary Mortgage Facility Introduction 1. The Secondary Mortgage Facility (SMF) is intended to add a significant element to the evolving Jordanian financial market, by serving as an intermediary between long-term lenders for housing and long-term investors. The benefits of the SMF to long-term lenders should be reflected over time in the terns and conditions under which banks would be willing to offer housing loans, thereby passing the benefits on to household borrowers (viz., mortgagors). Quantitative estimates of selected, perceived economic and social benefits of the SMF may be derived by estimating the value to lenders and households of having access to the form of financial intermediation provided by the SMF. Anticipated Benefits of the SMF 2. Benefits would arise primarily from the SMF's ability to help participating financial institutions (PFls) .reduce both interest rate risks and liquidity risks associated with their mortgage lending for housing. Currently, banks manage interest rate risk by specifying that the rate on a mortgage loan can be changed at the bank's discretion if its costs of funds changes. However, lenders have not attempted to use this discretion previously and there could be difficulties in doing so. The SMF offers lenders an opportunity to more formally link the rate on housing loans to the cost of funds, e.g., at a fixed spread over the cost of SMF funding. 3. Lenders manage the liquidity risk of lending for housing by only lending for relatively short terms (generally no more than 7 years) and limiting their overall housing lending.1 Even short-term commercial lending is not very liquid and thus banks maintain unusually high overall liquidity (55 percent in October 1995 for the banking sector as a whole). In principle, lenders could offer longer termns at rates high enough to compensate for the additional liquidity, but in practice they do not offer a choice and simply limit their long-term lending by price and non-price rationing. After the SMF begins to function and is perceived to be reliable, the liquidity risk of long-term housing loans would be sharply reduced, permitting a reduction in the price and non-price barriers to longer-term borrowing. 4. Benefits would arise for prospective mortgagors from competition among lenders causing them to pass through the benefits from improved risk management. Prospective mortgagors should see a combination of lower costs of funds and a longer term on the loans being offered, as well as greater interest among banks in pursuing more lending for housing, since funds for such lending would be in ready supply. 5. The value to consumers of these shifts in supply depends on the extent to which household borrowers are currently constrained. Each household is facing a supply curve of funds that is flat out to the underwriting criteria of the lenders and then becomes essentially vertical. Some households are borrowing less than the maximum possible, others are paying various shadow costs to expand their borrowing (and implicitly facing an upward sloping supply curve) and others, including many in the middle group, end up being non-price rationed. '/ The only exception currently is the Housing Bank, which has a number of special privileges that reduce its chances of ilhqWdity.

This curve shifts down and out to S2 once the SMF is firmly established. Households which would willingly borrow more than permitted currently have demand curves (e.g., DI) which are intersecting the supply of credit curve at a point beyond where it goes vertical; i.e., they are constrained by underwriting ratios and not by the explicit price of credit (the interest rate). Others may be at a point on a peculiar part of the effective supply curve, where they are expanding borrowing at an implicit extra cost by calling on faiily members and friends to serve as co-signers of the loan (e.g., D2). For both of these types of households, an expansion in the amount they can borrow generates substantial welfare gains, because of the gap between what they were willing to pay for credit and the explicit price of additional credit. In addition, any decline in the cost of borrowing in general would expand their existing consumer surplus from borrowing. 8. There are also those households which would not, at current interest rates, borrow more than pennitted if the term or underwriting criteria were relaxed (e.g., D3). For these households, any decline in interest rate on a 7-year loan would be a benefit, and any increase in borrowing that such a decline might engender would be valued at an amount equivalent to only about half of the product of the decline in interest rate times the expansion in borrowing. 9. In the case of DI and D2, the shift in S generates an increase in consumer surplus generally greater than simply the decline in the costs of credit. The incremental borrowing may be valued substanially more than the explicit market price, but these benefits are difficult to quantify. For example, the typical market-rate mortgage loan

If the interest rate is matained but the term extended to 10 years, the maximum size loan would increase by 20 percent. The maximum 15-year loan would be 40 percent larger. However, there is no market-based information on how much more this additional borrowing power is worth to curenly constrained households. An indirect indicator of consumer williness is the approximate 50 basis points that mortgagors in the U.S.A. frequently pay for mortgage insurance that enables them to buy more house by increasing their loan-to-value ratio from 80 percent to 95 percent. 10. It is not possible in this context to establish an equivalent figure for Jordanian borrowers. The anecdotal evidence is that most borrowers are borrowing the maximum permitted under current underwriting standards and thus there are relatively few households with demnand curves such as D3. Since the usual loan-to-value ratio is well below 50 percent, it seems likely that most are in category D I. In the absence of other evidence, it is assumed that all borrowers are of this type and that they value the ability to borrow 20 percent more at an average of 50 basis points. 11. It is difficult to predict how much the lenders might be willing to reduce their explicit price once the presence of the SMF irnproves their risk management position. However, it appears that the gross operating margin on housing loans is currently about 250 basis points, in contrast to a spread of 150-200 basis points in Westem developed econonies. This would suggest the potential for a reduction of up to 50 basis points from a combination of lower risks and greater competition. 12. In addition to the direct benefits to lenders and borrowers, there are some external public benefits which would also arise from improving the efficiency of investment and these should accrue to all participants in the financial markets. In particular, Bank sector work has indicated the need for a more active debt market, but there is relatively little Dinar-denominated government debt available in the market, and so far there has been no frequent issuer of a low-risk, high-liquidity longer-term debt instrument. The SMF would help to fill this void by being a relatively frequent issuer of low-risk debt securities (viz., bonds). Depending on market circumstances, many of these securities may have rates fixed for 3, 5, or 7 years or more. Market conditions would be reflected in their rates at the time of issuance. In addition, assuming some degree of trading is established, SMF bonds could provide a reasonable benchmark for capital market conditions and transactions. 13. Other benefits of the SMF are also likely to accrue, but they have not been included in the analysis here. The SMF could help to induce greater public awareness of the importance of analyzing credit risks in the absence of govemment guarantees, and also possibly to facilitate a reduction in the housing finance subsidies to low and moderate income households that the Government has been channeling through a special window at the Housing Bank (para. 19). Costs of Intermediation 14. The SMFNs costs of operation and of capital committed must be accounted for in detemuining net social benefits. The costs of operation are difficult to estimate with certainty, especially as a percent of the SMF's loan portfolio. To a great extent, the costs are independent of the volume of lending, while the volume of lending should be very sensitive to small differences in costs. Thus, there is a high degree of uncertainty as to the equilibrium level of costs per JD intermediated. 15. In total, the financial projections given in Annex 4 suggest that, provided the SME is able to generate a JDIOO million portfolio in 3-5 years, a spread of about 135 basis points would be needed to cover its costs. This spread could decrease as the costs of bond issuance are brought down and leveraging increases.

It is not clear solely from the perspective of the commercial viability of the SMF, described above and in Annex 4, that the SMF would generate net economnic and social benefits. The commercial superiority of SMF funding over deposits would be partly based on the fact that SMF funding would not fahe a 14 percent cash reserve requirement imposed by the Central Bank of Jordan (CBJ) on deposits.2 The direct and indirect benefits of the SMF need to be compared with the costs to detemine the economic rate of return separately from the issue of its financial viability. The Counterfactual 17. Implicit in this analysis is the assumption that the housing finance market in Jordan would remain unchanged in the absence of the SMF. To the extent that other adjustments could take place without the SMF, its benefits are overstated. However, it is difficult to discem signs that the basic nature of the mortgage and bond markets will change anytime soon in the absence of this project. Banks have reiterated their concem about the illiquidity of mortgage lending, the real level of govenmment domestic debt outstanding is shrinking, and bank syndications for raising medium-term funds have nearly completely replaced corporate bond issuances. 18. It could be argued that a private sector entity would undertake to provide SMF services independently if the market would value them highly enough. One reason that this event can be considered unlikely is the presence of the extemal benefits to the financial market expected from the SMIF, benefits which cannot be captured by a totally private entity (and which fomn the basis for CBJ support of the SMF). Another argument specific to Jordan is that the private institutions with the best chance of promoting an SMF, namely the Housing Bank and the Arab Baik, could reasonably view the SMW as undermining their competitive positions within the financial sector. But perhaps most telling is the observation that nearly all SMFs in the world have required some degree of govemment support or sponsorship. 19. A more likely subtle interaction of the SMF with the Government's role in the economy may be the facilitation of the political process of extricating the Govenmment from the continuing subsidy of housing lending to low and moderate income households. In retum for offering smaller borrowers loans for up to 15 years at only 7 percent, the Housing Bank receives a blanket tax-exemption on all of its housing loans. Such lending is a long- standing part of the special relationship that the Housing Bank has with the Government and which is expected to continue for the near future, despite other shifts intended to level the playing field in commercial banking. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Housing Finance and Urban Sector Reform Project for the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan are to improve the efficiency of the housing and housing finance sectors, to promote private sector development in land and housing production, and to reduce the government's role in both sectors. Through the establishment of a Secondary Mortgage Facility (SMF), the project will aim to improve the efficiency with which medium- and longer-term financial flows of mortgage lending are mobilized, to facilitate and foster competition in market-based mortgage lending, and to lengthen the term structure of mortgage lending. Through the implementation of institutional and regulatory reforms in the real sector, the project will also aim to improve the enabling environment for responsive private sector participation and competition in land and housing development for lower income households. The first of two project components is to create an SMF incorporating: (a) an SMF refinancing program; (b) equipment for the SMF; and (c) technical assistance to the SMF. The second project component is to make institutional and regulatory reforms; more specifically, to provide technical assistance to the Housing and Urban Development Corporation.
